Did you actually experience this?

As far as I know, Scrum doesn't say=
 much about testing (or coding) at all -
which is way many teams adopt XP p=
ractices for this part of the process.

XP, on the other hand, *requires* t=
hat the customer representative expresses
the requirements in executable (Q=
A style) acceptance tests, which need to be
ready at the end of the iterati=
on (sprint). It also encourages developers to
produce fully working, integr=
ated and unit tested code from day one.

So I'm not sure where your impress=
ion is coming from; to me it doesn't sound
like a team where that can happe=
n really has groked Agile software
development.

oject managers
> for sprints do not understand the need for engineering spe=
cs,
> hence they do not exist, or if they do they are after the
> fact.

I'=
m not sure what you mean by "engineering specs", but I also don't
understan=
d why the project manager has to understand their need for them to
be produ=
ced at the right time. It's the responsibility of the team to
produce what =
is needed when it's needed.

> There is no time in the plan for rework of b=
ad code.

If you need time in the plan for rework, you are not doing enough=
 of it.
Refactoring, as we call reworking code in small very controlled ste=
ps,
should be part of the developers minute-to-minute work. They should be =
doing
so much of it, so tightly intermingled with the rest of their work, t=
hat
it's impossible to measure how much of their time they are spending doi=
ng
it.

> There is no time in the sprint for rigorous QA.

QA should be an =
ongoing effort during the sprint, parallel to the rest of
the work. If ther=
e is "no time" for this, the team really is not a truly
Agile one.

leads to quantity not quality.

Agreed. But it has nothing to do with Agili=
ty.
